Open Data, Open Source and Open Standards

May 5, 2016

The Spring 2016 Digital Health Hack Weekend (7th and 8th May) will have a focus of Open Data, Open Source and Open Standards. ‘Open’ in all three contexts can be defined as:

“Open data and content can be freely used, modified, and shared by anyone for any purpose”



Open Data

The Open Data Institute defines open data as:

Open data is data that anyone can access, use or share. Simple as that. When big companies or governments release non-personal data, it enables small businesses, citizens and medical researchers to develop resources which make crucial improvements to their communities.

A number of relevant data sources are listed below:

  • data.gov.uk Health Data
  • Finding data at HSCIC
  • Open Health Data Platform Resources
  • Linking data across organisations
  • Forecasting using data
  • Various How To articles from the Open Health Data Platform
  • WHO Data and Statistics
  • UNICEF data and statistics
  • European CDC Data Tools
  • OECD Health Statistics
  • OECD Health Statistics II
  • Health Services Research and Health Care Technology
  • Data sharing repositories
  • World Bank Health Data
  • CDC Statistics
  • CDC Aging Data
  • Oxford Poverty and Human Development Data Initiative
  • NHS England - Midlands and East of England Commissioning region DataPacks
  • Maximal Information Coefficient (MIC) and Maximal Information-based Nonparametric Exploration (MINE) statistics
  • Met Office Datapoints
  • European Environmental Data
  • Global Boundary Data
  • Health APIs from ProgrammableWeb

For inspiration, you may also want to look at the fantastic EBM Data Lab, which is based at the Dept of Primary Health Care Sciences, University of Oxford, and also HealthMap, based in Children’s Hospital Informatics Program at Harvard Medical School.



Open Source

  • List of Open Source Health Software
  • Open MRS
  • cityEHR
  • cityEHR – Electronic Health Records Using Open Health Informatics
  • NHS Open Source Day



Open Standards

  • Standards allow for interoperability and data transfer
  • HL7 & FHIR
  • EMIS Health implements open standards for interoperability
